title: Copying Designs Doesnâ€™t Work, And Hereâ€™s Why
content:
Thereâ€™s a type of cognitive dissonance that haunts designers: the genuine desire to be truly innovative and original whilst simultaneously trawling the web for inspiration and design ideas.

I doubt many designers sit down with the intention of copying Airbnb, Apple, or Stripe. But theyâ€™re such beautifully-designed experiences that itâ€™s hard not to be inspired to some degree â€” even subconsciously.

Whilst the limitless optionality of a blank Figma board can be overwhelming, the answer is rarely to copy someone else. The plagiarism issue aside, itâ€™s tough to replicate the magic of another user experience and not lose the magic that makes it work.

Do you actually understand why itâ€™s worked? Have you lost the secret sauce somewhere in the replication? Can you then innovate your own ideas onto them?

Firstly, let me give you an example of an industry where itâ€™s been commonplace to copy what works from younger and more agile start-ups: banking.

Today I published some of the findings from a 900-day study of 12 banks in the UK called The UX of Banking. As a lifelong reader of Smashing Mag, I wanted to give you all a modified excerpt from that article and then some advice on how to effectively take inspiration from others.

Monzo Bank Was Heavily Copied In 2020

Back in 2020 (when I started this study), I was critical of how most of the incumbent banks handled basic card management features. They lacked context, the designs themselves were really poor, and there were basic usability issues.

New features, like freezing your card or showing your PIN inside the app, were simply added as new rows â€” similar to a settings page. This was the predictable risk of adding new functionality for decades without rebalancing the core user experience.

But, unburdened by how things used to be, Monzo, Starling, and Revolut seized the opportunity to design something that felt intuitive for this new paradigm. This example is from the UK, but itâ€™s true of many global brands, like Robinhood, Venmo, N26, and CashApp.

Since 2020, thereâ€™s been a noticeable effort to replicate what works inside the UK banking scene, and the experiences are looking very similar.

In particular, the order and positioning of the most common card management features â€” as shown above on Monzo in 2020. This is whatâ€™s clearly been a massive â€˜inspirationâ€™ to other banks.

This is true both of the visual aspects of design (i.e., how it looks) and the functional architecture of managing your card (i.e., how it works).

Barclays might have more than 80,000 employees, but it looks like they have the same grey Figma habits as the rest of us.

The Risk Of Copying

Now let me show you an example where copying can get you in trouble: chasing â€˜click-parityâ€™, copying a simple flow that you donâ€™t understand, and not considering that often the best experiences are the longest.

Here are the number of clicks it takes to order a new card with each of the 12 banks Iâ€™ve been following:

As an analyst (and at first glance), it might look like Metro has the best user journey. But in this instance, the number of clicks is the wrong metric to care about.

There appears to be very little positive correlation between what I believe are the better experiences (e.g., Revolut, Monzo, and Starling) and the number of clicks.

Rather, having too few clicks is more likely to be an indication that thereâ€™s not enough context (or that itâ€™s crammed into one screen).

Itâ€™s almost like the obvious cheat codes of design: use more padding, space things out, and give yourself more room to add context.

Letâ€™s consider a few nuances to this specific user journey (i.e., losing your bank card):

  • ğŸ“… Infrequent usage
    Most people arenâ€™t ordering new cards every month. So, this isnâ€™t a â€˜power featureâ€™, and theyâ€™re not hoping to optimize for efficiency.
  • ğŸ˜° Negative connotations
    Most of the time, youâ€™re ordering a new card due to a negative event (e.g., stolen, lost, or damaged). Youâ€™re probably already anxious, stressed, and frustrated.
  • âŒ›ï¸ Time sensitive
    People need a new card quickly. The context behind delivery speed is important, rather than the speed of ordering the card.

To summarize: People whoâ€™ve lost their card will likely be looking for reassurance and comfort rather than efficiency. Thatâ€™s the tone of the user journey, and as a designer, you need to be acutely aware of it.

Metro has so few clicks because itâ€™s essentially one screen with two buttons. You have no option to keep the same PIN (say, if youâ€™ve damaged your card at home), which means that you have to wait for both a card and a PIN to arrive.

The two clicks saved by not asking about this preference forced me to wait an additional two days before I could use my card.

And theyâ€™re the two metrics Iâ€™d measure success by for this user journey:

  • How good was the experience (qualitative)?
  • How quickly can they use their card (quantitative)?

If you were to copy Revolutâ€™s flow but remove the features your product doesnâ€™t have, that 11-click process might not feel the same.

Or, you could take inspiration from Monzoâ€™s â€˜card-selection screenâ€™, but if youâ€™ve combined it with another step they donâ€™t have, you may lose the magic of why it works.

Even banks, who largely have the same feature set, are replicating the same ideas with a really broad quality of execution.

Note: Itâ€™s an industry that should be relatively easy to replicate ideas, but demonstrates how subtly hard it can be.

The Doâ€™s And Donâ€™ts Of Implementing Inspiration

To be absolutely clear, Iâ€™m an advocate for leaning into the Familiarity Bias â€” a tendency for people to prefer (i.e., choose) products, services, and options that feel familiar to them.

So, here are a few handy doâ€™s and donâ€™ts of building familiar-feeling products, without losing that magic spark:

âœ… Things to do:

  • Try to identify the psychological biases that are in play.
    Is the user frustrated? Sad? Are they trying to avoid making losses, or is their decision-making skewed by something else? Ultimately, do they resemble the same biases affecting your product?
  • Can you lean into a well-known mechanism and save some onboarding effort?
    For example, TikTok popularized the â€˜swipe to watchâ€™ mechanism. Thereâ€™s no shame in using that same navigation style; your users will instantly feel more familiar with your product. Remember: familiarity is a shortcut to learning.
  • Be inspired by the inventiveness of the execution, not the visual stuff.
    Itâ€™s not productive to fall in love with Shopifyâ€™s checkout process and convince yourself that you need to copy it. Instead, try to identify how theyâ€™ve cleverly innovated about subtle and specific problems (i.e., managing global delivery addresses in one page without reloading).

âŒ Things to avoid:

  • Donâ€™t outright copy someone elseâ€™s design.
    You are probably only seeing 5% of the complexity, and the other 95% may include unexpected nuances that led to visible decisions.
  • Donâ€™t assume that you should have feature parity.
    In other words, just because a company you admire has features X, Y, and Z in the main nav doesnâ€™t mean you should. What do your users actually want to do?
  • Donâ€™t forget that your start-up isnâ€™t Airbnb, and you need to educate people on what you actually do.
    In other words, when a product becomes a household name, they often donâ€™t need to spend time (i.e., clicks) teaching the user what they actually do â€” everyone already knows. But you probably do.

I donâ€™t have the silver bullet of successfully replicating the magic of Apple (and if I did, honestly, Iâ€™d probably keep it to myself and make a fortune).

But, hopefully, this serves as an important reminder not to follow the competition blindly.
